00036 /**
00037  * @file event.h
00038  * @date 2008/05/01 16:15
00039  * @author Sergio Montenegro, Lutz Dittrich
00040  *
00041  * Copyright 2008 DLR
00042  *
00043  * Different events handlers
00044  *
00045  * @brief %Event management (header)
00046  */
00047 
00048 #pragma once
00049 
00050 #include "listelement.h"
00051 #include "timemodel.h"
00052 #include "debug.h"
00053 
00054 
00055 #ifndef NO_RODOS_NAMESPACE
00056 namespace RODOS {
00057 #endif
00058 
00059 
00060 /**
00061  * @class TimeEvent
00062  * @brief %Time management
00063  *
00064  * React on and handle time events
00065  **/
00066 
00067 class TimeEvent: public ListElement {
00068 
00069   friend void initSystem();
00070 
00071 protected:
00072   /// default list of all time events
00073   static List timeEventList;
00074 
00075   /// Time, when the event is activated to handle
00076   int64_t eventAt;
00077 
00078   /**
00079    * Periodical activation time of the event. If set to 0, the event is activated only once,
00080    * else it is activated with a period of this time.
00081    */
00082   int64_t eventPeriod;
00083 
00084 public:
00085 
00086   /**
00087    * Constructor
00088    * @param[in] name Name of the event.
00089    */
00090   TimeEvent(const char* name = "TimeEvent");
00091 
00092   /**
00093    * Pure virtual destructor.
00094    */
00095   virtual ~TimeEvent();
00096 
00097   static int32_t initAllElements();
00098 
00099   /**
00100    * Calls all time event handlers which eventAt < now (past)
00101    * and updates eventAt.
00102    *
00103    * @warning the execution order of event handlers for one timeslot
00104    *   is NOT guaranteed. If events A and B have similar schedule times with
00105    * t(A) < t(B) it could happen, that B is handled before A.
00106    *
00107    * @return the number of handle() called
00108    */
00109   static int32_t propagate(const int64_t timeNow);
00110 
00111   /**
00112    * Defines the time point when the method handle will be called one time.
00113    *
00114    * @param time Time to activate time event.
00115    */
00116   void activateAt(const int64_t time);
00117 
00118   /**
00119    * Like activateAt, but will be reactivated cyclic with the given period.
00120    *
00121    * @param startAt First time when the time event is activated.
00122    * @param period The gap time between two activations of the time event.
00123    */
00124   void activatePeriodic(const int64_t startAt, const int64_t period);
00125 
00126   /**
00127    * Handle the event. The default implementation of handle search for all threads
00128    * waiting on this event. This is the case, if the thread calls Thread::suspendCallerUntil
00129    * with parameter signaler a pointer to this event. The user can overload the method with
00130    * an own processing of the event.
00131    *
00132    * @warning 1
00133    * Handle is running in the context of the caller, maybe an interrupt handler.
00134    * So do it very short and avoid blocking functionalities inside the implementation of handle
00135    * like semaphores, IO activities and so on.
00136    *
00137    * @see Thread::suspendCallerUntil
00138    */
00139   virtual void handle(void) { }
00140 
00141   /**
00142    * The method is called once at system init during start up of the system.
00143    */
00144   virtual void init(void) { }
00145 
00146 };
00147 
00148 
00149 #ifndef NO_RODOS_NAMESPACE
00150 }
00151 #endif
